SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Mrs. Susan Therens

2. Your address: Mayenne Saskatchewan (now Prince Albert)

3. Date: March 23rd, 1962

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Heidelberg, Germany

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Michael Schneider, Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): Feb. 1st, 1914

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: came from the U.S.A.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.): I was 36 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: To make a better living

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Through relatives who had homesteaded in 1911

11. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How often you have been working on the farm since then?: The first two years we were here my husband helped supporting them from there on. We moved back to the farm and two brothers farmed together. One of his brothers had been farming since 1911.
1. Your full name: Miss Louise Thomson

2. Your address: My home town is [illegible]

3. Date: March 29, 1962

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Saskatchewan, Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Michael Thomson, farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): Feb. 1, 1919

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan; giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may say "I was in my teens," etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

[Handwritten note:]
There are no more homesteads. We are now living in the U.S.A. and trying to make a living.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Some thought we were crazy, some thought it was a good idea, and we took the risk.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   My husband, myself, and 7 children, the oldest 14 years old, 2 years old.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   We came by train as far as Assiniboia, then took a train from there, but they told us in the Hotel if we could not make it, there would be a mixed train coming along, but we could not afford to stay in the Hotel that long.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   My husband located a man from the town Barn to bring us in an open tow, seated Butter, stones below, and 2 feet fresh fallen snow. We had blankets collected the children all up and went, no track broken, no fence to go by, for miles my husband and the driver charged off melting along side the Horse, to stay on the hard road, we made it. So flesh the first day 3 o'clock stayed there one night started out at 9 in the morning got to Woodrow at 9 in the afternoon, it was very tough going, we stopped gave the children something warm, and started out again, got to Maymore in the evening, a man from the Hotel drove out 1/2 mile south of Maymore to tell our relatives, they came with horses and sleigh to take us. That winter we stayed with the relatives in a sod house, we settled right there near.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Maymore, it was too late to take up land.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Farming in the U.S.A. in South Dakota, the first winter we were here my husband helped Experimenting, then from then on him and his brothers farmed together. 3 of his brothers had taken Land up since 1911.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Horses carrying grain in a wheelbarrow. We liked it.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

How often? By what means of travel?

We did not travel except going to church on Sundays.

To my town 1 1/2 miles with horses, buggy or snowshoes.

My Grandfather died 1957 in Calgary.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Traveling on the prairie was hard but we liked it.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

We didn't travel very much except going to church on Sundays.

To Montana 1½ miles with Yvonne, Buggy and motorcycle.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Yes. Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? We liked the people and the beauty and made up our minds to stay from the beginning.
